repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - Fourth Health Project :
            Improving Equity and Quality of Care

abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            satisfactory, sustainability highly likely, and
            institutional development impacts substantial. Several
            lessons reinforce once again the need for simple, clear
            project design (focusing on fewer interventions would have
            been further beneficial); for strong implementing
            units' capacity (weak capacity at the provincial, and
            district levels was evident); for well defined
            implementation arrangements (particularly as it regards
            staff training, and technical assistance (TA)); and, for
            monitoring, and evaluation criteria, to be established
            during preparation. Moreover, key sectoral issues, i.e.,
            effective incentive systems, and laying the ground for
            successful public-private partnerships, were not adequately
            addressed. Notwithstanding, the prevailing weak
            institutional capacity, and lack of interventions, did raise
            awareness, among health personnel, and decision makers,
            namely, on the quality assurance program of the Special
            Assistance Fund, and on family doctors experience, which
            lead to the "substantial" rating of institutional
            development impacts. And, indeed, the good quality assurance
            program not only improved the quality of care, but provided
            empowerment, and "best practices", enabling staff
            to reduce costs (e.g., reduction in drug uses as a result of
            the rationalized drugs utilization). However, quality
            improvements, and services utilization should be further
            reviewed, while health center managers need further training
            and TA, and, drug management needs renewed efforts at the
            facility level.

repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - Fourth Health Project :
            Improving Equity and Quality of Care Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Fourth Health, Iproving Equity and
            Quality of Care, Project will improve health outcomes by
            giving provinces, districts and puskemas managers greater
            responsibility, authority, resources, and skills to enhance
            health care quality and equity. The project will
            specifically: (i) increase the authority and capacity of
            provincial and district health offices and health centers to
            plan and implement health programs as they deem appropriate
            to local conditions; (ii) to ensure that the provision and
            consumption of key health services conform to affordable,
            cost-effective standards of care; (iii) to improve access to
            utilization of these health services by the poor; and (iv)
            to improve efficiency in the delivery of basic health
            services (BHS).
